intro: Raphanus sativus var. scarlatinosus, commonly known as the red radish, is a cultivar of the radish plant characterized by its vibrant red skin and crisp, mildly peppery flesh. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other cruciferous vegetables like broccoli and cabbage. The plant typically grows to a height of 20–40 centimeters, with pinnately lobed leaves and a single, swollen root that serves as the edible part. It thrives in cool climates and is often cultivated in temperate regions for its quick growth cycle and nutritional value. The red color of the root is due to the presence of anthocyanin pigments, which also contribute to its antioxidant properties.
